question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the product of $10101_2$ and $101_2$. Express your answer in base $2$.
ground_truth:
Carry out the multiplication as you would with base $10$. There is no need to carry during the multiplication with base $2$.

$$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} &&&&1&0&1&0&1_2\\ &&&&&\times&1&0&1_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&&_1&1^{\text{ }}&0^1&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1^{\text{ }}_2\\ &+&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1&0_{\text{ }}&1&0&0_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&1&1&0&1&0&0&1_2\\ \end{array}$$Add it up for a final answer of $\boxed{1101001_2}$.

question:
$10101_2 = 1\cdot2^4 + 0\cdot2^3 + 1\cdot2^2 + 0\cdot2^1 + 1\cdot2^0 = 16 + 4 + 1 = 21_{10}$
$101_2 = 1\cdot2^2 + 0\cdot2^1 + 1\cdot2^0 = 4 + 1 = 5_{10}$
$21_{10} \times 5_{10} = 105_{10}$
$105_{10} = 1\times2^6 + 1\times2^5 + 1\times2^2 + 1\times2^0 = 64 + 32 + 4 + 1 = 101_{2}$
So $10101_2 \times 101_2 = 1010001_2$
Final Answer: $\boxed{1010001_2}$
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
inference:
$10101_2 = 1\cdot2^4 + 0\cdot2^3 + 1\cdot2^2 + 0\cdot2^1 + 1\cdot2^0 = 16 + 4 + 1 = 21_{10}$
$101_2 = 1\cdot2^2 + 0\cdot2^1 + 1\cdot2^0 = 4 + 1 = 5_{10}$
$21_{10} \times 5_{10} = 105_{10}$
Converting $105_{10}$ to binary:
$105 \div 2 = 52$ remainder 1
$52 \div 2 = 26$ remainder 0
$26 \div 2 = 13$ remainder 0
$13 \div 2 = 6$ remainder 1
$6 \div 2 = 3$ remainder 0
$3 \div 2 = 1$ remainder 1
$1 \div 2 = 0$ remainder 1
Reading the remainders from bottom to top gives $110101_2$
Therefore $10101_2 \times 101_2 = 10101_2 \times 101_2 = 110101_2$.

$\boxed{110101_2}$
ground_truth:
Carry out the multiplication as you would with base $10$. There is no need to carry during the multiplication with base $2$.

$$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} &&&&1&0&1&0&1_2\\ &&&&&\times&1&0&1_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&&_1&1^{\text{ }}&0^1&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1^{\text{ }}_2\\ &+&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1&0_{\text{ }}&1&0&0_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&1&1&0&1&0&0&1_2\\ \end{array}$$Add it up for a final answer of $\boxed{1101001_2}$.
